intro: Diplycosia caryophylloides var. longipes, commonly known as the long-stemmed waxflower, is a shrub native to the coastal regions of southern Australia. It is characterized by its dense, compact growth habit and its ability to thrive in sandy, well-drained soils. The plant produces small, fragrant, pink to purple flowers that bloom in spring, adding ornamental value to gardens. Its leaves are narrow and evergreen, providing year-round visual interest. This variety is particularly valued for its drought tolerance and suitability for coastal landscapes.
